node.plaintext:
Getting something new started is always an adventure.  So many questions. So
many choices. So many potential roadblocks.

In this series, we want to document and share some of those core moments. Maybe
they will be fun to read. Maybe they will help inspire your thinking.  And just
maybe they give a few teachings. We shall see together~

This whole adventure started with an almost joke. 

"Why not move to the country side, somewhere like Karuizawa, somewhere near the
ski slopes? It'll be quiet, safe from large populations.  It'd be easy to host
friends and family visiting.  It could even give us some space to try out some
new ideas like making t-shirts or beer."

That simple semi serious suggestion set in motion a great search for a new place
and endless hours of listing out potential futures.

From there, we've come to spend an entire month living in Hakuba.  Normally,
Hakuba is a quiet inaka town with just a few thousand people.  During winter
it's full of skiers and snowboards, often from abroad.  When the summer brings a
calm quiet winter brings a live busyness.  After some thinking and consideration
of alternatives, Hakuba quickly became the potential base of operations.  The
places we've looked at range from small quiet personal homes all the way up to
aging pensions or hotels. By far our favorite is a 2-year abandoned hotel like
house, but can't be used as a real hotel. With choices upon choices how do we
decide?

First, we look at everything we can.  The cute tiny houses had their appeals.
 Small, simple, easy to maintain.  Pretty well located to skiing and town
activity.  A few of them had a little extra space usable for a business, like a
gelato shop or a tiny ramen bar. But honestly, they were a bit expensive for
what they had going on.  And moving into them would risk living a life just like
we left behind in Tokyo, only in the mountains.  In a word, they were
uninspiring. Our eyes hold no sparkle for those nice but generic homes.

Second, we considered some very remote pensions.  These were big, large enough
to host 20 or more visitors.  Full with small bars, dining spaces, hang out
spaces, lovely little bath areas.  Even better, two were at the base of ski
slopes.  Literal minutes walk away from snow. But the biggest downside was that
biggest upside.  They were so far removed from anything else.  People? off in
the distance.  Groceries? 20 minutes drive away.  Hospital? an hour away. And
overall love put into the buildings? A little short there.

That takes us to the best things we've seen so far.  At the top of a very lovely
hill, yet still quite close to the rest of civilization, is a much loved
pension.  12 well kept rooms.  A cute shred space and kitchen.  An amazing ski
slope view and forest all around.  It's cute, it has possibility, but it's at
the top of a giant hard to navigate hill and has some risk of structural age.

Contrast to that is the hotel that could not be a hotel.  While not as centrally
located, off in the quiet recreational area of a town near to Hakuba, it has the
charm of possibility. More space than any other property.  Better built than any
other property. More odd regulations than any other property.  But so much
potential.  Opportunity to host friends.  Guests.  Family.  Space and
facilitates to make new things and to teach others how to do so as well. It's so
exciting. It's also a ton of work. Maybe more work than just two people can
handle.

So which choice shall we make? Only in the next post shall we know!
